unnormalised: Okay, so, I was just filling up my scooter at the petrol pump yesterday, right? And it got me thinking... why are we still talking about litres when talking about fuel efficiency? Like, "kitna deti hai?" is the first thing anyone asks about a new bike or car. And it’s always in km/L. It’s like, stuck in our brains, isn't it?
normalised: Okay, so, I was just filling up my scooter at the petrol pump yesterday, right? And it got me thinking... why are we still talking about litres when talking about fuel efficiency? Like, "kitna deti hai?" is the first thing anyone asks about a new bike or car. And it’s always in kilometer per liter. It’s like, stuck in our brains, isn't it?

unnormalised: But seriously, think about it. Litres are a measure of volume. Petrol and diesel prices are also set per L. Makes sense for buying, but for judging efficiency? Hmm. Maybe not so much.
normalised: But seriously, think about it. Litres are a measure of volume. Petrol and diesel prices are also set per liter. Makes sense for buying, but for judging efficiency? Hmm. Maybe not so much.

unnormalised: I remember back in college, my professor was saying how miles per gallon (mpg) in the US is equally weird. It's like, clinging to the past, isn't it? Even though they're *supposed* to be all about innovation.
normalised: I remember back in college, my professor was saying how miles per gallon in the U-S is equally weird. It's like, clinging to the past, isn't it? Even though they're *supposed* to be all about innovation.

unnormalised: Imagine this: you’re comparing two cars. Car A gives you 20 km/L and Car B gives you 25 km/L. Seems like B is way better, right? A 5 km/L difference is a big deal!
normalised: Imagine this: you’re comparing two cars. Car A gives you twenty kilometer per liter and Car B gives you twenty five kilometer per liter. Seems like B is way better, right? A five kilometer per liter difference is a big deal!

unnormalised: But let’s flip it. Instead of km/L, let's talk about L/100 km – how many litres you need to travel 100 kilometers. For Car A, it's 5 L/100 km. For Car B, it’s 4 L/100 km.
normalised: But let’s flip it. Instead of kilometer per liter, let's talk about liter per one hundred kilometer – how many litres you need to travel one hundred kilometers. For Car A, it's five liter per one hundred kilometer. For Car B, it’s four liter per one hundred kilometer.

unnormalised: Suddenly, the difference doesn't seem as massive, does it? But here's the real kicker: if we convert this to fuel consumption *cost*, then the difference gets really clear.
normalised: Suddenly, the difference doesn't seem as massive, does it? But here's the real kicker: if we convert this to fuel consumption *cost*, then the difference gets really clear.

unnormalised: Let's say petrol is ₹100 per L (approximately – it fluctuates so much these days, na?). Car A will cost you ₹500 to travel 100 km. Car B will cost you ₹400. That’s a ₹100 difference! Over, say, 1000 km a month, that’s ₹1000 saved. Boom! Suddenly, Car B's advantage is crystal clear in terms of money saved.
normalised: Let's say petrol is rupee one hundred per liter (approximately – it fluctuates so much these days, na?). Car A will cost you rupee five hundred to travel one hundred kilometer. Car B will cost you rupee four hundred. That’s a rupee one hundred difference! Over, say, one thousand kilometer a month, that’s rupee one thousand saved. Boom! Suddenly, Car B's advantage is crystal clear in terms of money saved.

unnormalised: My friend Rohan was telling me about his truck. He’s always complaining about its mileage, saying it barely manages 5 km/L. But when I asked him how much he spends on fuel per month running his delivery business, he gave me some vague answer. Dude needs to calculate his L/100 km!
normalised: My friend Rohan was telling me about his truck. He’s always complaining about its mileage, saying it barely manages five kilometer per liter. But when I asked him how much he spends on fuel per month running his delivery business, he gave me some vague answer. Dude needs to calculate his liter per one hundred kilometer!

unnormalised: It’s all about perspective, ya know? Maybe if we started thinking about fuel efficiency in terms of L/100 km or even better, rupees per kilometer (₹/km), we’d make smarter choices about the vehicles we buy and how we drive. It’s about seeing the real cost, not just the "kitna deti hai?" bragging rights.
normalised: It’s all about perspective, ya know? Maybe if we started thinking about fuel efficiency in terms of liter per one hundred kilometer or even better, rupees per kilometer (rupee per kilometer), we’d make smarter choices about the vehicles we buy and how we drive. It’s about seeing the real cost, not just the "kitna deti hai?" bragging rights.

unnormalised: Think about those fancy electric scooters too. They boast about range – like 150 km on a single charge. But what's the energy consumption in units per 100 km? Companies need to start putting *that* info front and center.
normalised: Think about those fancy electric scooters too. They boast about range – like one hundred and fifty kilometer on a single charge. But what's the energy consumption in units per one hundred kilometer? Companies need to start putting *that* info front and center.

unnormalised: So, next time someone asks "kitna deti hai?", maybe we should start answering in L/100km or ₹/km instead. Let's change the conversation, one petrol pump trip at a time! What say?
normalised: So, next time someone asks "kitna deti hai?", maybe we should start answering in liter per one hundred kilometer or rupee per kilometer instead. Let's change the conversation, one petrol pump trip at a time! What say?
